feedgroup.feedtitle: CSS for the Next Billion Users
feedgroup.feedcontent: Ire Aderinokun lays out how to approach writing CSS so that the next billion users coming online can access your sites.

feedgroup.feedtitle: When Not to Build a Design System
feedgroup.feedcontent: Some times when it doesn't make sense to build a full design system.

feedgroup.feedtitle: Good Product Manager, Bad Product Manager
feedgroup.feedcontent: An essay on what good and bad product managers do and say.

feedgroup.feedtitle: 15 Rules Every UX Designer Should Know
feedgroup.feedcontent: A list of 15 things to keep in mind when designing for users.

feedgroup.feedtitle: How Paper Wireframing Will Make You a Better Designer
feedgroup.feedcontent: From Medium. An article on the Why and How of doing your wireframing on a good old piece of paper.

Philosophical questions over lunch. Help me answer them:

1) What is Layout for? What is itâ€™s job?

2) What makes a layout broken? Why is it broken? What defines broken-ness?

3) What does a good layout accomplish? How do we know?

— Jen Simmons (@jensimmons) April 20, 2018
12 lessons learned to help make better buttons for design systems.
I didn't have a full understanding of serverless sites and apps. This helped me understand.

![image](assets/img/infinite-scroll-js.png)
Adam Khoury shows how to create an infinite scroll script using some basic JavaScript.
Smashing Magazine teaches how to find different types of research participants for gathering data in a UX/UI project.

feedgroup.feedtitle: Effective Design Strategies for Extra Large Footers
feedgroup.feedcontent: One Extra Pixel lays out some strategies for design and content in large website footers.
Designmodo covers some important things to remember when creating a multi-step UI element.

feedgroup.feedtitle: Designer Tips: How to Get Great feedback

feedgroup.feedcontent:
![image](assets/img/traversy-git.png)

Brad Traversy takes you through an explanation of Git, how to use Git on the command line for your local repository, and how to push your changes to Github from the command line.

feedgroup.feedtitle: A Primer to Web Accessibility for Designers
feedgroup.feedcontent: Web accessibility is the developer's and designer's responsibility. Here are some quick and easy ways to get started designing accessible websites.

feedgroup.feedtitle: Ethical Design: The Practical Getting-Started Guide
feedgroup.feedcontent:
Via Smashing Magazine:

"This article explains how unethical design happens, and how to do ethical design through a set of best practices. It also helps you understand how you can plant the seed to change the meaning within the company you work for and in the design community, even if you are not part of the management layer."

![image](assets/img/v-fonts.png)

A simple resource for finding and trying variable fonts. Just move the sliders to change the fonts in real time.

![image](assets/img/javascript-templating.png)

Learn how to create a simple Javascript template using data from HTML attributes.

feedgroup.feedtitle: Playlist: Getting Started With Adobe XD
feedgroup.feedcontent:
![image](assets/img/adobe-xd-playlist.png)

A playlist from the [DevTips for Designers channel on YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/user/DevTipsForDesigners). Travis Neilson walks you through how to switch from Photoshop or Sketch to Adobe XD.

![image](assets/img/grid-maker.png)

A tool to visually learn CSS Grid Layout. When you're done with your grid, you can export the HTML and CSS to add into your project. Supports the repeat() and minmax() methods.
Chris Coyier of CSS-Tricks shows how to create a notched box effect using CSS that makes the corners of a box look cut off.
Tim Kadlec tests how fast Google AMP is by running 50 different news stories through a page speed test. The results are surprising.

feedgroup.feedtitle: Web APIs You Might Not Know Exist
feedgroup.feedcontent:
![image](assets/img/web-apis.png)

With the introduction of HTML5, the Web got a lot of new toys to play with. But this video shows some JavaScript APIs that you might not know exist.

feedgroup.feedtitle: Where to Sit at Your Next Meeting
feedgroup.feedcontent:
![image](assets/img/where-to-sit.png)

According to Vanessa Van Edwards, where you sit at a meeting table says something about your intent in the meeting. Find out what the seats mean and what strategy you should employ at your next conference or meeting.

![image](assets/img/adobe-color-cc.png)

A great color wheel to use for your next design project. Explore palettes created by other users or create your own. The tool offers an easy to way to create a palette from one starting color.

![image](assets/img/mavo.png)

Mavo allows you to create lightweight web applications without a back end. All of the data is stored locally in the browser or it can be saved remotely on Github or another location of your choice. This site is built with Mavo.

aboutcontent:
### Welcome to the Front End Feed!

My name is Brian Haferkamp. I'm a Front End Developer with Tyndale House Publishers, a book publisher near Chicago. Like most web developers, I find myself searching online a lot for how to make magical things happen with a website or for my team. I'm also trying to keep up with the huge number of new frameworks, libraries, tools, and ideas in the constantly changing web design and development landscape. In the past I've use my Twitter account ([@brianhaferkamp](https://twitter.com/BrianHaferkamp)) to curate those resources, but it's not the best tool for going back and finding the things I've posted. 

I wanted to create a space where I could collect some of the best articles, tools, and videos that I watch on design and front end web development, but I didn't want to spin up a full blog. I've tried that in the past and just haven't been very successful at keeping it up to date. I don't want to have to login and then post. Lazy, I know, but I have a life. That's when I came across a solution that has solved my blogging needs for now.

The code that changed my blogging woes is called, Mavo. [Mavo.io](https://mavo.io) is a front end web library developed by MIT (lead by [Lea Verou](http://lea.verou.me/)) as a way to appify an HTML website without the need for a traditional back end setup. All of the data is stored in a JSON file on Github and is fed into the shell every time you access the site. No servers to set up and no databases to maintain. Best of all, changes can be made entirely in the browser. In fact, I've written this entire page in the browser. Mavo content editing supports a rich text editor and markdown (I prefer markdown).  That's been the real key to me sticking with the site. I can login, add a new link, save it and then get on with life. Sometimes I get fancy and add some images for the tools or videos, but it's not a major barrier. I can make changes on my phone, tablet, or computer. It's suuuuper simple. 

As far as content is concerned, I wish it were not quite so random. I post here when I find something that's worth sharing or I want to reference in the future. I try to make a post every day, but I'm not perfect. The best way to check out the feed is to add the link to your home screen (on mobile or desktop) and check back every few days. I don't currently have RSS set up. 

If you have any questions about the site or Mavo, [send me a tweet or DM on Twitter](https://twitter.com/BrianHaferkamp).
